parts: Name this molecule whose “good” variety is HDL and whose “bad” variety is LDL. This molecule is the precursor of all steroid hormones and helps maintain membrane fluidity.
Tangier’s disease is caused by a mutation in ABCA1 transporter protein. This usually accelerates the formation of these fat-laden cells from macrophages, greatly increasing cardiovascular risk.
The recently approved monoclonal antibodies alirocumab and evolucumab target this protease that cleaves the LDL receptor.

answers: Richard Nixon’s early morning visit to the Lincoln Memorial [accept any descriptive answer that implies Richard Nixon going to the Lincoln Memorial]
parts: Identify this impulsive trip taken in the early hours of May 9, 1970 by Richard Nixon, who worried his bodyguards by insisting on speaking to the young student protestors he met along the way. Description acceptable.

The protesters Nixon conversed with were demonstrating against the invasion of this country. During the Vietnam War, this country’s Khmer Rouge regime allowed the Viet Cong to hide within its borders.
Nixon’s policy of reducing American presence in Vietnam through “Vietnamization” included an increased support role for these things. The Iroquois version of these things was nicknamed “Huey.”
Name this movement which supports the creation of a Jewish homeland in Israel.
Modern Zionism was founded by this journalist, who created the World Zionist organization.

This first Professor of Jewish Mysticism at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem and friend of Walter Benjamin broke with Hannah Arendt after she published correspondence where he criticized the “malicious” tone of her articles on Eichmann without telling him.
Name this play in which Hally demands that the servants Sam and Willie call him by the title name after hearing that his crippled father is returning from the hospital.
Master Harold… and the Boys was written by this South African author of Blood Knot and The Road to Mecca.
In Master Harold...and the Boys, Sam reminisces about helping Hally make one of these items but not being able to use it with him, since he was sitting on a Whites Only bench.
Name these highly branched polymers named after their tree-like appearance. Many of these molecules such as PAMAM are currently being investigated for use in catalysis and drug delivery.

One way that dendrimers could be used for drug delivery include formation of these spherical aggregates in solution to encapsulate the drug. Lipids can form these structures with hydrophilic heads and hydrophobic tails.
Dendrimers can be synthesized through a series of addition reactions, such as this reaction that involves a nucleophilic conjugate attacking an alpha-beta unsaturated carbonyl.

answers: Boston Molasses flood [or Great Molasses Flood; prompt on “Molasses flood” with “in which city”]
parts: Name these documents which include a Roman collection attributed to Apicius, which contains an epitome written by Vinidarius. Fannie Farmer tried to standardize measurements in one of these works published in America.

Carol Gold analyzed the evolution of concepts of domesticity and national identity in cookbooks in this country. This country’s capital city of Copenhagen is home to many Michelin Star restaurants, including Noma.

Fannie Farmer’s cookbook was named for the city where this event took place. In this event, the rupture of a large tank at the Purity Distilling Company killed 21 in a flood of the namesake substance in the North End.

answers: French horn [or technically E-flat horn, I guess]
parts: Name this music critic who notably praised Beethoven as “a purely romantic composer” compared to the likes of Haydn or Mozart, part of his Kreisleriana papers.

In his criticism of Beethoven’s fifth, Hoffmann describes his admiration for the E-flat major second theme of the first movement played by this instrument. Beethoven’s ninth symphony contains a famous solo for this instrument.

Like everyone who has ever heard Beethoven’s fifth, Hoffmann expresses his surprise at the striking simplicity of the symphony’s principal motif, which is often described as this knocking at the door.
Name this painting in which two guitars hang on a wall above a Spanish gypsy dancer in black and white whose shadow is dramatically thrown onto the wall behind her.

El Jaleo was painted by this American who scandalously showed Virginie Gautreau in a tight black dress in Portrait of Madame X. Four young girls stand under Japanese vases in his The Daughters of Edward Darley Boit.

El Jaleo hangs in a museum founded by and named after this eccentric Boston art patron. Sargent painted a portrait of her in pearls in front of ornate floral walls, as well as a portrait of her wrapped in white after a stroke.

answers: A. S. Byatt [or Antonia Susan Byatt]
parts: Using forms such as a court trial and a jump rope rhyme, twelve hanged maids interrupt Penelope’s experience during The Odyssey in The Penelopiad by this Canadian author of Cat’s Eye and The Handmaid’s Tale.

In this author’s Ragnarok: The End of the Gods, a child evacuated from the Blitz reads a book of Norse myth. She also wrote about the relationship of Randolph Ash and Christabel LaMotte in Possession.

This author’s Dream Angus contains several modern and one archaic story about a Celtic god who is turned into a swan. He created the Botswanan investigator Precious Ramotswe for The No. 1 Ladies’ Detective Agency series.

answers: Lady Macbeth of the Mstensk District [or Ledi Makbet Mtsenskogo uyezda]
parts: Name this opera, in which the duet “Si, pel ciel marmoreo giuro” is sung. Its leitmoifs include a “kiss” theme played at the end of the opera and a theme in which a woman’s cries of “Salce” are echoed by an English horn.
This composer of Otello and Aida was also inspired by Shakespeare in an opera which ends in a chorus claiming “Everything in the world is a jest,” Falstaff.
In this Shakespeare-inspired Shostakovich opera, Katerina has an affair with Sergei, killing her husband Zinovy and his mushroom-obsessed father Boris. It ends with her dying on the way to Siberia.

answers: a state [or Seeing Like a State]
the Mafia [or Mafiosi; Sicilian Mafia; accept any answer along the lines of organized crime]
parts: Name this entity that Max Weber defined as having a monopoly over the legitimate use of force. They have sovereign control over an area of territory which may include a specific group called a nation.

This political scientist famously sought to explain state formation with the aphorism “war made the state and the state made war.” This person sought to explain Contentious Politics in a book written with Sidney Tarrow.

Tilly compared war and state making to the extractive properties of these organizations. Diego Gambetta traced the origin of these organizations in Italy as providers of private protection and guarantors of transactions.

answers: Hillary Clinton’s crimes and intelligence leakers [accept equivalents or more specific examples like “Hillary Clinton’s email server and White House leaks”]
parts: This former communications director lasted only 6 days before being dismissed, probably due to a profanity-laden interview and his accusal of Steve Bannon of performing autofellatio.

This deputy assistant to the president and member of the Strategic Initiatives Group left on August 25. This Hungarian-American with ties to the alt-right never obtained security clearances to work on national security issues.

Rumors abounded that Trump was planning on firing Attorney General Jeff Sessions after tweets where he criticized Sessions’ “very weak” stance on these two issues, both go-to bogeymen for the Trump Administration.
Name these systems which exhibit quenched disorder. The aforementioned Edwards-Anderson model of these systems can be solved exactly to determine the free energy below the critical temperature.

The Edwards-Anderson model is similar to this model of ferromagnetism, which consists of spins on a lattice which interact with their nearest neighbors. The two-dimensional version of this model is one of the simplest to display a phase transition.

This model of spin glasses is a mean-field model which was proven to be exactly solvable by Giorgio Parisi. Like the Edwards-Anderson model, it considers two spins interacting, but allows an infinite range of interaction.

answers: Willy-Nicky letters [accept telegrams or correspondence for “letters”; accept any answer indicating letters sent between Wilhelm II of Germany and Nicholas II of Russia; accept William for “Wilhelm”]
Franz Ferdinand [or Franz Ferdinand Carl Ludwig Joseph Maria; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name these documents, another of which lamented an “outrageous crime” that resulted from “the unscrupulous agitation that has been going on in Serbia.” Description acceptable.
The Willy-Nicky letters were mostly sent at the end of this month during a namesake “Crisis” that led to World War I.
The July Crisis was kicked off by the assassination of this Archduke and heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne along with his wife, Sophie, in Sarajevo.

answers: Hina [accept Hinatea or Hinauri or Hina-moe-aitu]
parts: Name this Polynesian hero who legendarily used his fishhook to pull up many islands out of the sea and is killed by the vagina dentata of Hine-nui-te-po.

In different myth systems, this goddess associated with the phases of the moon is alternately Maui’s mother, wife, or sister. In some stories, he saved her from being molested by an eel and used her hair to make his sun-lasso.

In the myths of these Polynesian people, Hine-nui-te-po is the ruler of the underworld. Her father and husband Tane pushed apart his parents the sky goddess Rangi and the earth mother Papa in this culture.
This author of The Guide for the Perplexed attempted to codify the entirety of the Talmud in his Mishneh Torah. He is sometimes known as “Rambam.”
This other Jewish thinker took a Kabbalist approach to Maimonides in 13th-century Spain, where he lost the Disputation of Barcelona to Pablo Christiani. He is nicknamed “Ramban.”
Maimonides and Nachmanides both belong to this subgroup, a type of Judaism characterized by its origin in Spain, Provence, North Africa, or the Middle East.

answers: Polisario Front [or Frente Polisario; FRELISARIO; Frente Popular de Liberacion de Saguia de Hamra y Rio de Oro]
parts: Name this demonstration called by Hassan II where 350,000 people met up in Tarfaya. This event was not resisted by the Sahrawi people, who would later wage a 16-year guerrilla war.
The Green March was organized by a monarch of this country, whose northern Rif Region tried to break away from Spain. The Casablanca Conference occurred in this country ruled by the Alaouite Dynasty.
This guerilla organization leads resistance against Morocco and Mauritania in Western Sahara. Ould Daddah’s failure to conquer this organization led to his downfall.
For a cloud to form, the temperature must reach this point. When this value is close to the air temperature, relative humidity is high.
These kind of clouds have an anvil-like top and flat bases. They are often associated with thunderstorms and tornadoes.
Another kind of cloud, typically found higher up than cumulonimbus clouds, are these thin layers of gray clouds. The Sun is usually visible as a bright spot behind them.
Name this play, in which the title servants, Claire and Solange, frame Madame’s lover and fail to serve her a cup of poisoned tea after playing at being her in a series of power fantasies.
This French ex-con and playwright of The Maids also wrote The Balcony and The Blacks.
This other Genet work features tension between the prisoners Maurice and Lefranc as they ostensibly argue over the girlfriend of the soon-to-be-guillotined Green-Eyes.

Name this one-act play, adapted into the story “A Jury of Her Peers,” in which Mrs. Hale and Mrs. Peters hide evidence which hints that Mrs. Wright killed her abusive husband for strangling her canary.
Trifles was written by Susan Glaspell, a playwright who also fictionalized the legacy of this reclusive female poet from Amherst, Massachusetts, in her play Alison’s House.

Glaspell founded the Provincetown Players, a group that discovered Eugene O’Neill and this author of Renascence. A woman freezes to death making clothes for her son in this poet’s “The Ballad of the Harp-Weaver.”
